passage_text: As you can see, clay tile costs more, but it also lasts longer and the color holds longer. No surprise here. Larger roof = more tiles and labor hours needed = larger cost. So if your two-story home has 1,500 sq ft of roofing, then the average cost of a new concrete roof could be around $6,000 to $15,000. For a clay roof, it could be $10,000 to $45,000.

Metal roofing is the most expensive and can cost up to $30,000-$40,000 for large roof replacements. The quality of the roofing material will also determine the cost of roof replacement. For example, asphalt shingles can cost anywhere from $50 for average quality to $150 or more for the highest quality (per square). The following are figures for the average cost of roof replacement: 1  Asphalt: $700-$3,700. 2  Slate: $17,000-$84,000. 3  Wood shingles or shake: $7,000-$20,000. 4  Concrete tile: $8,000-$21,000. 5  Ceramic clay tile: $12,000-$21,000

Fixing a simple roof leak in an asphalt or metal roof costs just $350 on average, according to the Lehigh Valley Roofing Company. Different materials may cost more to fix, with clay or concrete tile repairs averaging $360, wooden shakes at $420 and basic slate roof repairs averaging $500 as of 2014. The average asphalt roof replacement project in the U.S. costs $18,913 as of 2014, according to Remodeling Magazine. This figure includes removal and disposal of the old roof, new underlayment, flashing and drip edges, as well as new asphalt shingles.

Total Costs. Based on the prices listed above, a replacement roof with mid-grade materials can cost $10,000 and up. A 24 square roof with asphalt shingles and a single layer of tear-off can cost as little as $6,700, while the same roof with zinc or copper roofing can cost as much as $30,000.
